awd_titl_txt: Measuring the Dynamics of Excitons in 1D Semiconductor Quantum Wires with Quantum State Resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: In photovoltaic (PV) devices it would be ideal for every photon that impinges on the device to be absorbed and for at least one electron and one hole to be separately collected as current and electricity with little or no loss of energy within the system, regardless of the color of light or energy of the photon absorbed. PV devices that incorporate semiconductor nanoparticles (NPs) as the absorbing medium offer the advantages of tunable absorption energies through size control and large absorption efficiencies. When light with energy in excess of the band gap of the semiconductor NPs is absorbed, the photogenerated electrons and holes relax down to the lowest-energy states. The efficiency for the charge carrier relaxation depends on numerous factors, including the densities of electron and hole states, the roles and rates of different energy-transfer mechanisms, the temperature, and the chemical environment of the NPs. The research team is synthesizing NPs with varying sizes, shapes, semiconductor materials, and chemically passivated surfaces. Several optical spectroscopy and microscopy techniques are being implemented, and new models are being developed to characterize the relaxation dynamics in the semiconductor NPs. The ultimate goals of the research activities are to not only characterize the relaxation dynamics of the carriers, but to develop novel nanostructures with properties that are optimal for the light-to-electricity conversion of PV devices. The research project is highly interdisciplinary, and graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds, are gaining the expertise needed to become the next generation of scientists. The educational mission of the principal investigator extends beyond the research team as educational videos on the physics of light and on the importance of alternative energy sources are being developed and disseminated to the public and local schools.

Technical Description: The relaxation dynamics and efficiencies of photogenerated electrons and holes in semiconductor nanoparticles (NPs) ultimately limit the yields of photovoltaic devices that incorporate NPs as the absorbing medium. The goals of the research are to accurately characterize the intraband relaxation dynamics (IRD) and mechanisms for carrier relaxation in semiconductor NPs. Specific research activities that include nanoparticle synthesis, electron microcopy and imaging, and optical spectroscopy in both the time- and frequency-domains are characterizing the IRD of the electrons and holes. The team is paying particular attention to the roles of dimensionality and the densities of states on the rates and efficiencies of electron and hole relaxation to the band edge. Carriers in one-dimensional semiconductor quantum wires (QWs) and belts (QBs) can have translational kinetic energy and delocalization along their lengths. This dimensionality gives rise to a continuum of states that can be accessed during carrier relaxation. These one-dimensional NPs contrast those of widely studied zero-dimensional quantum dot (QD) and two-dimensional quantum platelet (QP) systems. Time-resolved transient absorption experiments are performed on NPs with contrasting dimensionality to identify the role of the states, kinetic energy, and momentum on the carrier IRD. A new model, quantum-state renormalization is being developed to help unravel the dynamics from complicated transient absorption spectra recorded on ensembles of the NPs. The efforts are complemented through a long-standing collaboration with the synthetic group of William E. Buhro (Wash. U.) and a new collaboration with the ultrafast spectroscopy group of Martin Zanni (U. Wisconsin).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Loomis group investigated the efficiency and relaxation dynamics of photoexcited charge carriers prepared above the band-edge states in colloidal semiconductor nanoparticles (NPs). Specifically, the experiments included both steady-state spectroscopy and time-resolved transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy measurements on samples of CdTe quantum wires, CdSe quantum platelets (QPs), as well as CdSe, CdTe, and CdSe/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) suspended in solution.

It was determined that the quantum-confinement states that contribute to the optical spectra of all of these samples shift to lower energies with photoexcitation, a phenomenon termed quantum-state renormalization (QSR). From a general chemistry perspective, QSR is a result of the promotion of an electron from the valence band to the conduction band and the formation of a hole, or an electron-deficient region, in the valence band. This excitation consequently alters the electron density within the semiconductor nanoparticle, and the screening and interactions of the carriers change. From a physics perspective, it is also likely that the photoexcitation results in Frolich interactions, or the interaction of the charge carriers with the polar lattice of the semiconductor that also gives rise to coupling with phonons, or lattice vibrations. As a result of the photoexcitation, the valence and conduction bands flatten and shift as do the quantum-confinement states, as illustrated in Figure 1(a) and (b). The TA data collected on the NPs are comprised of differential spectra, the difference of the absorption spectra of the excited and unexcited samples, Figure 1(c), and the QSR results in positive induced-absorption and negative bleach signals throughout the entire spectral region. There are also bleach signals in the TA spectra associated with population of the photoexcited carriers in the quantum-confinement states.

There are several key signatures of QSR present in the TA data that stand out, see for example the data collected on CdTe QDs included in Figure 1(d)-(f). First, there is an induced-absorption signal, just below the energy of the lowest-energy absorption feature, red, when exciting above the band edge. This feature is negated at long times by the bleach signals associated with carriers in these shifted lowest-energy states. Skeptics of QSR have incorrectly suggested this induced-absorption feature is associated with biexcitons. The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum and the long-time bleach signal associated with the carrier population are nearly identical and associated with the energies of the shifted band-edge states. The PL of a semiconductor NP is a single-photon process, and it cannot be associated with biexcitons, especially when using low excitation fluences. Second, the induced-absorption and bleach signals associated with QSR are present throughout the entire spectral region, including above the excitation energy, as indicated in Figure 1(e). Third, the QSR depends on the states occupied by the carriers, and the states shift by dissimilar energies. Fourth, once the states reach the band-edge states, the energetic shifting of the states remains constant.  

Throughout the funding period, significant efforts were on accurately identifying the contributions of QSR and carrier populations in the TA data. While the investigation of QSR is interesting from a materials perspective, it was shown that it must be accounted for when attempting to characterize the timescales and dynamics of carrier relaxation in NPs. The roles of the specific facets of the NPs were investigated in part by recording spectra as a function of their surface ligation. For wurtzite CdSe QPs, it was determined that photoexcited electrons only transfer to methyl viologen ligands at the polar small-edge facets of the QPs, and not at the non-polar long-edge or flat facets. The trapping of excitons does occur on the long-edge facets of the QPs.

Included in the broader impacts of this award is a formal, funded training program Recruitment and Retention of Underrepresented Graduate Students initiated by Loomis that aims to prepare outstanding students with less experiences who might be considered at-risk for the rigors of graduate school. Through this program, students identified during the admissions process are brought to campus over the summer prior to their first year program to provide additional training and coursework to strengthen their foundations. The students participate in experimental workshops to learn laboratory methods and best-practices in areas the students identified they were not comfortable in. The students also participate in a formal mentoring program. This involves a Chemistry peer student program and formal faculty mentoring in addition to their mentoring from their principal investigators. Loomis regularly meets with these students to discuss progress, study skills enhancement, research progress, and career development.
